thread.title: In Putting the Team First, Players Put Themselves at Risk
thread.title_full: In Putting the Team First, Players Put Themselves at Risk - The New York Times

author: William C. Rhoden
title: In Putting the Team First, Players Put Themselves at Risk
text:
Mets Manager Terry Collins raised eyebrows Friday when he suggested that his star pitcher Matt Harvey could start three times during the World Series. Noting that Jacob deGrom looked “like he could use some time,” Collins, asked about the possibility of giving Harvey an extra start, said, “There’s a possibility, yeah.”
Really? Must be World Series fever, when ego and manning up overtake common sense and pragmatism.
If Harvey really is called upon to pitch three times, either his agent, Scott Boras, should drop Harvey as a client or Harvey should cut ties with Boras for allowing it to happen.
Boras had it right during the summer when he raised the issue of an innings limit for Harvey and his surgically repaired elbow. Harvey, he suggested, would not be overused or misused.
The message was clumsily delivered, but the underlying idea was correct then and continues to be: If the player doesn’t look out for himself, he certainly can’t count on the team to do so.
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage On Baseball: How Mets Coach Brought Out Daniel Murphy’s Power OCT. 24, 2015 Lucas Duda’s Breakout Performance, at Plate and on Instagram OCT. 23, 2015 For the Mets, Pennies Saved Add Up to a Pennant Earned OCT. 22, 2015 Even in the Language of 1908, the Cubs Come Up Losers OCT. 22, 2015 The overriding instinct for most players is to take care of the team, take care of teammates, do whatever it takes to win.
For Harvey, vilified when he seemed to back his agent’s assertions, this may mean pitching three times in the World Series, even if it means putting his career at risk.
But if an injury occurs while he goes the extra mile, will the franchise go the extra mile for Harvey and offer him a rich contract for damaged goods?
Of course not.
But this is the World Series and all bets are off. Duty to team trumps duty to one’s self. Teams rent players’ bodies. They pay many millions for the use of strong arms, powerful legs, broad shoulders. Brains.
